thread.title: AL.com All-Access: For one night, Auburn turns its frown upside down
thread.title_full: AL.com All-Access: For one night, Auburn turns its frown upside down

author: Kevin Scarbinsky | kscarbinsky@al.com
title: AL.com All-Access: For one night, Auburn turns its frown upside down
text:
Comments 
If this were the team so many people expected it to be, Auburn 30, Kentucky 27 would be considered something of a disappointment for the winners. 
The Tigers missed an opportunity to put the game away in the second quarter by settling for field goals, they gave up far too many yards all night and they needed one Kentucky drop after another to escape. 
But for an Auburn team forced to readjust its goals from making the playoff to reaching a bowl, it's hard to be let down after your first SEC win in 50 weeks. 
The Tigers survived primarily because they executed at winning time. 
At the end of the first half, the defense got a three-and-out with a third-down sack by Davonte Lambert, and the offense hit a key pass from Sean White to Peyton Barber to set up a long field goal from the weapon known as Daniel Carlson. 
In the fourth quarter, the offense put together an 11-play touchdown drive that consumed 5 Â½ minutes, with Barber carrying the rock and White hitting go-to guy Ricardo Louis for an explosive play. 
When the offense failed to run out the clock, the defense saved the game with a big pass breakup by Jonathan Jones and a fourth-down sack by Justin Garrett. 
Put those plays together, and the Tigers came down on the positive side of the half-full, half-empty conundrum. 
By the light of the morning after, it's obvious that Auburn still has miles to go to win even one more conference game. Next up is Arkansas on the road, and Brandon Allen may not have to throw a pass except the Auburn defense is far too inviting far too often. Kentucky inexplicably went away from tailback Boom Williams , who carried only 16 times despite averaging 7.1 yards a tote and busting a 60-yarder. 
Bret Bielema, who's taking Saturday off to prepare, will turn the Auburn game into his Super Bowl. If you thought he was excited after getting a call against Alabama, imagine what his level of glee would be after getting a win over Malzahn. 
Auburn's schedule gets even more challenging from there. 
For one night at least, the Tigers were able to generate their own enthusiasm and overcome their own flaws and win a conference game on the road. Not everyone believed they were capable of pulling that off. 
So the team that needed something good to happen made it happen. That's worth at least 24 hours of a frown turned upside down. 
That's my take. What's yours? Bring it on AL.com All-Access, our daily chat, confessional and troll convention from 10-11 a.m.
